Craig Ferguson and David Letterman took the last vestiges of late night "as we knew it" with them. That's not to say the people left behind weren't talented (Conan is an all-time fave who'd been doing it two decades by that point). But that was the end of the "you watch it from beginning-to-end and it has a cohesive feel" days of late night shows. The transition from Leno to Conan back to Leno to Fallon was such an instructive exercise in terms of what late night was and what it would become.

I think late shows can be described in a few points:  1) Outside of this video, and the movie "Late night with the Devil", I routinely and completely forget that Late Night shows even exist. They are the radio of television; and television is the Telegraph of the visual medium - something that continues to exist, seemingly by accident. An artifact of a bygone era. Antiquated, but occasionally useful under specific conditions, like an ISP having a network outage, or a hurricane knocking out cellphone towers.  2) Opening monologs are rarely funny, even more rarely non-political. This isn't to say the writers don't have talent - I'm sure they are very good, but rather it's because the pace and schedule of Late Night shows is constant. I don't need news reporters cracking jokes, and I don't want comedians forcing me to hear their opinions about current events. They are separate beasts, and it's painfully uninteresting to hear the most tepid, milquetoast interpretations of whatever happened a week ago. So, what is the point of that monologue including current events and politics, if for nothing else but sheer desperation?  3) Interviews are rehearsed, borderline choreographed routines that are only even possible because the guest is shilling for some widget I don't care about. I don't want an advertisement in the middle of a discussion genuine or not, so why would I put up with it in the most bland, uninteresting manner possible? Imagine if JRE were 3 minutes long, and half of it were Joe and the guest just repeating the guests Social Media accounts over and over again. Late Night interviews have nothing to offer because they _can't_ offer anything - it is by design. Nothing to say but "buy my product". Nothing to discuss but "how great my product is". They are atrociously bad, and in the rare occasion where one of the mid-show bits hit well, the "interview" will bleed out all forward momentum.  4) Predictable to the point of pointlessness. Assuming younger people have ever even _watched_ Late Night talk shows, they already know precisely what the stages of it are going to be: Monologue, Cheesy bit(s), Lackluster interview, Music/Interview. It's been this way for as long as I can recall, and there's literally no reason that it _needs_ to be this way. It's a talk show! How about the interview takes up half of the show, then you have someone play music, then more interview? How about Friday's are: music, an extended monologue, a cheesy bit, and more music? What about: Bit, Music, Interview and _no_ Monologue if there is nothing interesting going on? It's unclear to me if any of this has ever even occurred to the people who run these dead horse shows, but I can't name a single instance where any Talk Show has ever strayed from this format. It's painfully obvious that the spirit of creativity has completely given up roaming the halls Late Night shows in America decades ago.
Late night is analogous to say a former boomtown, drilling for oil, mining, everyone came, what have you. And when the profits dried up and it becomes less appealing, it just turns into a quiet pass through town only few love to visit.
I think late night television is also dying because people can get more direct access to celebrities through social media, subscriptions and cameos. Celebrities are also appearing on shows that are better suited for YT.

I've always felt very strongly that the only good late night shows were the Daily Show with Jon Stewart, the Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson, and the Colbert Report (and I suppose Last Week Tonight, as well). The problem is that those three ended in fairly rapid succession, CC struggled to fill he void of the Colbert Report. The Nightly Show with Larry Wilmore was good but didn't get the viewership it needed. And when Trevor Noah replaced Jon Stewart he comprehend abandoned the pioneering format the Jon had spearheaded and returned the bland and dying traditional format. After about a year, I just stopped watching Noah's TDS. It simply wasn't what I had loved about the show and it seemed to have no interest in being what was good about it in the first place, leaving John Oliver and Last Week Tonight as TDS's spiritual successor in Trevor Noah's wake. However, since Jon has come back to steward the show, I do feel that there has been a legitimate return to form of TDS's part, and I love and enjoy each of the revolving hosts. You should really do a video essay on the revival of TDS post-Noah, because I think it proves that the future of late night is political satire and commentary on the news through an irreverent lens. We've all watched as the actual media fails on its duty to hold people in power accountable or call them on their lies, and that is the void that TDS under Jon Stewart filled and that it (and other shows) can fill again

Seems relatively obvious, and if it isn't I think that shows a terrible grasp of history.  Of course Late Night talk shows weren't going to last.  Does anyone really expect that in 2134 The Tonight Show, or even television itself, will still exist?  Hell, it's highly doubtful that nation-states like the United States will still be around.  200 years ago there wasn't even a Germany or Italy.  France is on its Fifth Republic.  What an odd way to live, ignorant of what came before so you are blind to change to come after.  A mistake to think the world was always the same way it was when we were born, and will always be that way.  You see it all the time, Late Night TV is just a smaller example.  These aren't institutions, and even real institutions quickly fade.

When I was a child I would visit my grandparents every summer for a couple of weeks. My grandfather ran a theater, and I would usually go with him each day to open up. My grandmother would usually bring us dinner around 6, and then she would take me back home. On Sundays I watched Lawrence Welk  with my great-grandmother, but every night we watched Johnny Carson. I remember how she would laugh and say things like, "Oh, that Johnny is too much! I declare! He outta be ashamed of himself." I always looked forward to those two weeks and watching late-night TV with Mama Cole. That was paradise for a child. During the day I watched movies, ate popcorn, and drank unlimited soda, and then I got to stay up as late as I wanted.

This was fantastic. Just a bit of trivia from an old lady comedy nerd who has been watching Late Night not just since before you were born but before I was born (VH1 used to rerun decades-old full episodes late at night): Conan has been doing wildly popular and beloved remotes with a cult following since his first show began in 1993. These (and his behind the scenes antics) were beholden to Letterman and an absolute reverence for his comedy. The thing I find most remarkable is that, by continuing to do episodic remotes, Conan keeps the heart of a very particular part of Late Night that Letterman was solely responsible for alive and beating. Letterman's zany, ridiculous, ludicrous and outright demented remotes and behind-the-scenes walk-throughs are legendary and hold up to this day. My respect for Letterman as a person has diminished over the years but watching him every night as a little girl was so formative.  P.S. I kinda suspect those that own it will keep network TV limping along putting less and less money and effort into it and making more and more profit off of streaming (plus all that juicy streaming data) until a good chunk of boomers have died and that will be that for the entire concept of not just Late Night but network television altogether.

You believe Jay Leno chose to leave? Actually what happened was *NBC* (fearing they were going to lose Conan to another network) offered him "The Tonight Show" *IF* he would wait 5 years, at which time Jay would be put out to pasture. This was not Jay's choice.  RE: "...after decades of having it."  When Jay was replaced in 2009, he'd hosted for almost 17 years. So not quite decades.  RE: "You gracefully hand over the position to Conan O'Brien,"  Yes, as *NBC* instructed him to do, thereby sparing Conan potential criticism from Jay's audience for how he got the show at Jay's expense.  RE: "...and then you decide that you miss the attention."   Well, actually it was more like *NBC* missing the profits from having a "Tonight Show" that was #1 in late night. You see, when Jay handed over the show in May of 2009, it had been consistently at the top of the ratings for years, and after a week with Conan as host, "TTS" was losing to "Late Show With David Letterman." This was not a good sign to *NBC.*  RE: "So you come back,"  Yes, when *NBC* decided they were actually about to make a huge mistake letting Jay go to *ABC* to host a new show that would oppose Conan.  RE: "...destroy Conan's career for a year or two..."  Jay's 10pm show only ran 3 months, and Conan had a new show at *TBS* about 10 months after he resigned from "The Tonight Show." So, nowhere near two years.  RE: "...and then you decide you're tired and you retire once again."  Jay Leno did a stand up gig the day after setting his face on fire. The guy doesn't seem to get tired. What happened was after four more years of hosting "The Tonight Show," *NBC* (once again) decided to retire Jay. I have little doubt that if they'd let him stay, he would probably have hosted that show for as many years as Carson did.   Honestly, Mr. Burback, your conception of what happened is both factually inaccurate and mischaracterizes Jay's Leno's part in it. The entire story was made public years ago in the excellent book *"The War For Late Night: When Leno Went Early & Television Went Insane"* by NY Times journalist Bill Carter. That's a book people who want to judge should read, and not just cling to false narratives.
Both Meyers and Kimmell acknowledge their YouTube-only audience, I think it's clever

I am older and more conservative now than I was in my youth. Despite this, Colbert's satire of Glenn Beck's "Let's all act like we did after 9/11" in which Colbert responds with a gas mask and shotgun saying "Ok!" Is still the funniest thing i have ever seen on tv.
There is a real aspect of longevity in Late night that I am shocked hosts never figured out (except for one). That is the power of absence.   Carson, who was number 1 in late night his entire 3 decade run, only hosted upwards of 3 nights a week.  He was always in Vegas doing standup or out playing tennis.  The ratings would dip with his absence and then surge on his return. People missed him and it gave other voices an opportunity to shine, creating a network of goodwill towards Carson.   Absence made the heart grow fonder. Even though it wasn't calculated to prevent personality burnout, that's exactly what it did. And America adored him for his entire career despite divorces, alcoholism, and minor scandal. He is a Presidential Medal of Freedom recipient for goodness sake, the highest civilian honor one can receive.   If Jimmy Fallon had taken more nights off we wouldnt have gotten sick of his fake laugh or Colbert's smugness.
It's a shame considering how vital and epic Johnny Carson was

The problem with late night is simple.  They're all woke which alienates half of the potential viewers, they aren't as funny as the men they replaced, and there's more alternatives in the time slot than ever before.  Also, the death of the celebrity is upon us.  Not as many people are as famous as there used to be so the pool of interesting people has vastly depleted.  I should point out that Conan wasn't fired the first time just because Jay wanted his slot back - not even close.  Conan's ratings took a deep dive from where Leno was and never showed signs of recovery.  His TBS stint was also at the bottom of the ratings heap - by a lot too in an already struggling late night format.  80's sitcom reruns on Nick-at-nite beat him - often.  Contrary to what many are saying below praising him - he wasn't as funny or as quick witted enough for the position compared to a Letterman, Ferguson, or Jay.  As for Seth, Cordon, Kimmel, or Colbert - well, they are painfully uninteresting and comedy seems to evade them at every opportunity.  Remember when Colbert had the dancing vaccines?  It went viral not because it was funny - it went viral because it was cringe.  Not a good look to sell a show.  I didn't even bring up Fallon because I forgot he existed.

I am old.  I grew up with Carson, and even remember Ed Sullivan in my childhood. The last late night show that I regularly watched was Conan.  Now I just catch clips on YouTube.  I tend to be more annoyed at the non-American hosts (did you mention Oliver?) than the others.  Not sure why.  Like you mentioned, tv shows (and tv magazines and postal interactions) used to be our only connection with celebrities.  Most celebrities could opt to maintain a low profile, disappear off the radar, and then pop up on a show occasionally.    These appearances were carefully crafted and rehearsed.  All those on-air moments and hilarious interview questions that appear spontaneous were practiced just an hour before and the live audience reaction is also rehearsed and encouraged by signs, shills, and fluffers.  The late night shows, I think, for decades, mainly served as a way to showcase/promote a current movie, tour, event, or product.  It was not just the public desiring access to the celebrities, it was more the corporate media craving convenient access to the public, plus advertisers. Win-win-win.  The access to multiple free media by the public has totally changed this.  The model that has worked since the 70s has become a clunky, outdated dinosaur.

A lot of that is political jokes. Political jokes are the new 'f' word jokes which are the new 'racist' joke. (Follow me) Long time ago, 50's and 60's, if a comedian was bombing, they'd throw out a racial joke to try and win the crowd back...but sometimes they'd go overboard. When people stopped laughing at those jokes in 70's and 80's, then it was the "shock" of using the 'f' word in a joke. They started out being clever uses...then just, unwarranted, then hacks would litter their entire set with them to win a crowd. That doesn't work anymore so now comedians just do a bunch of "I hate Trump" "Trump is dumb" and "Trump is bad"...and that's fine if you sprinkle in a joke here and there to win a crowd, but I watched a monologue of Colbert and it was literally nothing but Trump jokes, they weren't even funny they were just sentences to try and win a crowd over. Now every comedian does that. It's why Greg Gutfeld has the highest rated "talk show" now...because he is clever and it's not just wall-to-wall Trump hate. As someone who was an avid watcher of late night television prior to the strike and am watching it religiously now that it's back, I do agree that yes, as a platform and an institution, Late Night TV is dying. But I still think that Late Night TV can bring something to the scene that still has value in a world where nobody has cable and our attention spans are slowly leaking out of our ears. The use of short segments that can be published individually on youtube and that make use of a returning cast of characters gives a sense of familiarity. Seth does this incredibly well, with the incorporation of his writers and the cue card guy as characters who have their own inside jokes associated with them. Like yes, there's a lot of other similar content out there, but watching Seth regularly feels like you're a part of the "in crowd." (If you're looking for a great example of this, please please please watch Corrections. It's legitimately one of the funniest things on the internet right now.)  Another example of a unique way that late night tv has been able to stay relevant is the absurdity of John Oliver's antics. This man and his team have HBO money. In my opinion, they use it incredibly well. They use HBO's resources and connections in a way that the average content creator wouldn't be able to do as easily.  Look idk if I've made my point well enough but overall, I think the shows that have been able to adapt have still have gas in the tank, but the format for sure is not what we remember it as kids.

jimmy fallon is insufferable 11:25
the last time i visited my parents, they were watching old episodes of the merv griffin show. disparate celebrities with absolutely nothing in common were brought on and given random conversation topics. whenever a comedian was brought on, they would get a moment to do a segment from some standup or a comedy skit.  i saw joan rivers before she'd had any work done. she was hilarious.   there was an episode where carol burnett and roddy mcdowell were both on, and carol told him that when he was a kid starting in lassie, she went to meet him somewhere and get his autograph, because he was her pretend boyfriend. his laugh was like a little flute. he was a twink.   sometimes the celebrities would be angry with each other or not get along. phil spector went on several times and every time he did, all the other celebrities were openly exasperated that he was there lmao. he was such a little prick. he'd like, insult them. on national tv, in front of a live studio audience. he met his match with eartha kitt, who insulted him back in a sultry purr and got a roaring laugh from the audience, from merv, and from me.   i was riveted, is the point. these were true human interactions among naturally talented people. they were dressed up nicely and behaving politely, but ultimately if they were having fun, they'd act like it; and if they weren't, they wouldn't. i was like, why aren't shows like this anymore?   it's because late night talk shows are for press and bothering each other and nothing else. you only go on a talk show to promote your book, new movie, or new album. you have a rote script that was approved by your team. the host tries to get a rise out of you somehow. it's all the same.   no matter how charming or not charming the host is, it's all the same. the format died long before the internet replaced it, in my opinion.  and it did. the internet did replace it. when i was thinking about what replaced merv, i thought of "hot ones." i don't watch hot ones, but that's the vibe. the activity is controlled, but the interactions have a spontaneity that talk shows lack. you can't say "my book is about xyz and available for preorder now" with your mouth full of buffalo sauce.

Before social media, younger audiences (18-35) would watch 'must see' television together or discuss it the next day - there was a communal feeling that these hosts were the voices for each successive generation - Boomers had Carson, Gen X had Letterman, Millennials had Conan (and not to mention, John Stewart), and Gen Z has well, hmmm...? Well they have YouTube and Social Media, which defers or even divests any feeling of a shared cultural zeitgeist (IMO). Perhaps these generational voices are just too difficult to locate today, as the kind of cultural touchstones that create connectedness are lost in a virtual sea of content - ironic in an era where 'social' is the preferred adjective for most of the media we consume today.
Corden is a small petty little man who abuses his small circle of influence - I'm not surprised people see him for who he really is outside of his show. But Fallon's TV persona is completely manufactured as well. I really don't understand how the audience doesn't sense the artifice and insincerity during his interviews. His laugh is so affected, and he panders like an idiot to his celebrity guests. Fallon's true personality is only on display when he does something competitive, and it becomes obvious he's someone who hates to lose. Which is fine, as it reveals at least something authentic, but that part of him is in complete contrast to the wide-eyed innocent schtick that gets really old really quick  - makes my skin crawl.

Because like, without the high-production value, without the writing staff to provide the same jokes (they're not great but they're something), and without the live celebrity guests, late night hosts had practically nothing fun to do on camera. Some of their segments could be the same. I don't see why it is that discussion worthy. I listened to it, but I'm not seeing it. Shows should publish in the formats of the most common household video playing devices. That changes over time. Right now there is 3 really widespread video watching formats, televisions, desktop computers, mobile devices. Each one has pros/cons to leverage. I think the current setup of filming a scheduled TV broadcast and then editing it for publishing on other formats is sensible and will last for some time.
And now here the sag is protesting for a higher percentage of residuals. That's like me building a house and selling it. Then expecting a yearly payment for having done the job, just because someone is still using that house. No, the companies that produce the physical media, that costs money, deserve to make money from those physical discs and whatever else. That's why they make residuals. Writers are greedy and want more of that money. The average writer in Hollywood makes 120k a year. Which isn't much in California. But they're literally writers, their job can be done anywhere. Zoom group calls for meetings and brainstorming and so on. They should move if they want more spending power.

I tend to feel the politicization of the late shows is specifically one of the contributing factors of their demise. they were already long stagnant, but that didn't help. Because you took what was already an extremely insincere highly controlled and scripted format, where you never believed any of the hosts were behind any of their jokes or comments, and have them become obvious political mouthpieces of the network. When people tune in to the late show to have something fun to watch after the day is done, not get more of what was already on tv. It's why Jimmy stayed popular and fairly liked, vs his rivals. His only failing being that his show was already stale and past the format's prime, so he remained on top solely because he was apolitical, but that alone cannot float the show.  at the same time it's impossible to overstate the influence of podcasts, especially people like Joe Rogan. Who can still get super heavy hitting people on his show and instead of mundane safe questions looked over by a team of suits, and limited to the 20 minutes or so before the commercial break, you can have well over an hour of unscripted natural conversation.  I *wanted* to still like late night. I loved Letterman, and Leno, and Craig Ferguson. They were genuinely funny, and they were great at interviewing people. When Letterman, Leno, and Ferguson left, I tried Jimmy and I tried Colbert, but I never found either one funny. ESPECIALLY Colbert. And when he set the trend for becoming ultra political in 2016, it was just too much.  And Corden similarly was never funny nor likeable.  Seth i would argue is the best of the current crop, and ironically the best suited to the current politicized format, since it basically just becomes an extension of the role he played on SNL, which he always did extremely well. but again, I just dont like the heavy focus on politics in late night these days. So I just stopped paying attention. and I figure a lot of people have a similar story of having liked these shows before, but just not liking the current crop of hosts and the style.

Conan and Fergie Ferg were the last 2 great late night hosts.  They were at least funny.   But the concept of late night and why it exists.... IMO.... died years ago.  Even while Ferguson and Conan were still on.  All late night was originally was to take a peak behind the curtain of what a celebrity was like..... and for them to pitch their movie, album, comedy show, or whatever product they were pushing.  Since the creation of social media.... we know what celebrities are like personally.... and they're fucking cringe inducing terrible people for the most part.  And the products Hollywood is producing is essentially ideological propaganda for the last 5-10 years.  So.... only the most basic bitches of society find that "entertaining" or enthralling.  The death of late night is the exact same reason why the bona fide movie star died.  People know everything about celebrities... and they're not that great.... and movies have in general - sucked ass for the better part of a decade.  Celebrities are less actors, musicians, comedians, whatever nowadays and more just glorified idiot activists spewing their dumb opinions every opportunity.  Nowadays.... you don't have to be famous to do that bullshit and get attention.  So nowadays celebrities are just famous.... average Joe idiots who pretend to be highly insightful and intelligent because.... they're famous.  As if fame makes one smarter.  They play pretend for a living for fucks sake.... or write songs, seemingly never growing up mentally past the age of 20.  I mean.... look at Tommy Lee or Nikki Sixx from Motley Crue. Those dudes are in their SIXTIES but desperately and pathetically cling to their 20s.  They act incredibly immature, they blatantly obviously due their hair and style their hair to look younger, and dress like they're still in their 20s... maybe 30s.  It's.... sad.  And I'd hate to pick on just then they're just a great example.  Pretty much all celebrities are like this.  They never grow/ mature... on a mental, intellectual level.  They act like they have but their opinions they spew are so simplistic and completely lack forethought and foresight they're the opinion a 20something would have with practically 0 life experience.  Only thing celebrities are seemingly knowledgeable on are..... drugs and plastic surgery.  Because they're glorified junkies and petrified to age so they've had every surgery under the sun to cling desperately to their youth.    The veil on celebrities has been truly lifted thanks to social media and those with brains see celebrities for what they are..... mentally immature, narcissistic - idiots.  Celebrities used to be marveled at.... now I think most with a brain just laugh at them.  Like the dancing monkeys they've chosen to be.... for our entertainment.  But they're entertaining for all the wrong reasons now.... on how pathetic and dumb they are.  Yes there's still the massive sector of society that's equally retarded as celebrities and still idolize them.  I mean... how else would the Kardashians be were they are without such a sector of society.  But a lot of people are just completely turned off by what they entertainment puppets have to say.... or what they even do nowadays.  There is very little luster to traditional entertainment celebrities nowadays to the point I think entrepreneurs have surpassed them in star power.  A sit down interview with Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, Tim Cook, etc. Would likely garner more viewers than another interview with.... say.... Tom Cruise.... or Dwayne Johnson.... or Margot Robbie (she's kind of the "it" girl... for her 15 minutes in Hollywood).  The point is... people see celebrities for what they are.... actors who just play pretend for a living. Musicians who act like teens well into their 40s and beyond because they've never had to mature beyond that point in life.  The "mystery" of celebrities is gone.  And the apparent massive mental issues 99% of them have are so much more apparent.  Be it legitimately insane to just being conceited narcissists... that's pretty much a majority of entertainment celebrities.  What rational person would look up to that or be intrigued by that?  Couple that with the reveal of how everyone suspected for YEARS on how Hollywood truly operates to create these "stars" to be true - blow jobs for parts in movies/ shows and likely record contracts - being a "celebrity" is a lot less appealing. I mean hell.... the Kardashians claim to fame was literally a sex tape one had with a flash in the pan rapper.  The narcissistic matriarch of that family turned that seed tape into a billion dollar family enterprise.  Which is cool I guess..... but.... demented.  And outputting for sane people.  Said matriarchs kids are filthy rich now.... but are also filled with more plastic parts tab my 2021 Toyota Camry.  And they all look fucking miserable.  They only hit they appear to have in life is buying shit and their materialism.  Which is.... sad... and pathetic.  If they lost their fame/got "canceled" i bet they all would slip into severe depression and I wouldn't be shocked if I read about one or two of them killing themselves. I feel like 99% of celebrities are on some sort of psych drug for their "depression" and "anxiety."  One obstacle in their life would push them over the edge.  Because most of them are legit fucking mental cases.

If you're 26, live TV wasn't a thing for you for a long time. The idea of sitting down to watch TV, zapping around to see who was on started to die in 2010 (that's when youtube started growing hugely and twitter started being relevant). People who watch late night content watch the news before going to bed and even them are being swooped over by Youtube. They're still fun and a lot of their bits are better than a lot of big content creators content, but now they're being cut and put on their channel as well. They might not need the absurd production, but, they generate ideas for youtubers. Internet feeds from TV still, but also from itself.

The issue with what writers get paid is a catch-22.  On principle, I am in favor of them being paid fairly.  I don't want to make it seem otherwise.   But in practice, the reality is that between streaming services, cable channels, etc., there is A LOT more content being made these days and A LOT more places to watch some portion of that content.  While great in theory (meaning there's more jobs to be had), it also means that the average TV show being made today is getting fewer people watching it, since there SO many more options today.   Not to mention that with Youtube becoming bigger and bigger over time, the time people spend watching videos (including this one) is time NOT spent watching a traditionally produced TV show (whether on a network or streaming service).     While actors are of course generally paid a lot more than writers, even many actors aren't getting paid as much for a TV show made for a streaming service today than they were for network TV in it's hey-day.   As just one example, while the amount they were paid is a A LOT for the average person, when Fuller House came out on Netflix, the returning cast from the original show was making less money per episode than they did on the original show (and each season of the new show had fewer episodes).  And that is without adjusting for inflation over the course of the 2 decades that passed between the original show ending and the new one starting.    Heck, Eddy even says himself in this video that he doesn't watch live TV on regular networks anymore and waits to stream them after the fact.  That's an understandable choice, and one that many make these days, but these shows don't make as much money off of those views as they do when more people watch live.  The more live ratings that they get, the more eyes that are on their show and by extension the commercials that run during it.   When views diminish, so does the amount they can get advertisers to pay, and by extension the money that can be put into the show (or the risk of it getting canceled).   While on demand/ streaming views do help and ads do generally run during them, it's typically fewer ads than the live broadcast.     And this whole video is specifically about how late night TV is dying with the ratings dropping substantially (they didn't even replace James Corden with someone else after he left), yet it ends talking about the writers strike and showing the hosts supporting their writers.  That's all well and good, but it becomes difficult to make an argument to pay more money to the staff on TV shows that are severely dropping in the ratings and therefore not bringing in as much money as they once did.     By no means am I saying that the hosts deserve to make as much money or more as they did when the ratings were higher.   The point is simply that it's hard to justify pumping more money into something that is clearly having substantially diminishing returns.

The real problem with late night television lately has been it's gotten overly political. More often than not, they're very partisan and basically play to the same views that the Hollywood elites have. They regularly smear the right and fawn over leftist tropes like gun control. We as viewers want to be entertained, not informed. Fox's show Gutfeld has quietly become one of the highest, if not the highest, rated late night show because it's so much of what the other talk shows are not. Granted, I'm not necessarily saying I agree or disagree with any of these hosts' views but as a country built on limited government and the ability to express views freely, these hosts seem to miss the point of what the free market is about: Giving us what we want to hear, not need to hear.

As far as a representative of the international audience goes, I've been along for the ride since the early moments of daily show with Jon Stewart, as the era of then high-speed p2p-sharing came about. I've never known any other format than the digital realm for late night shows, so it's strange to put this video into this context. The appeal that Stewart had with TDS (and still has now with his current show), the Colbert report, and now predominantly Seth Myers, is the good political satire and the occasional relevant interviews in a smart format. Any other content would simply feel like a waste of time - and the brits have already perfected that realm with their gameshowesque approach (Mock The Week, QI, Have I got news for you etc.)
John Oliver (and his team, of course) is doing seriously good investigative reporting. And his format is perfect for YouTube. Glad you mentioned him.

Having a cable package and also having a life schedule which suits TV schedules is just not in the modern lifestyle. I work a 30hour job with a weekly rota. It gives me time for my hobbies and freelance work while still having a level of stability. Scheduled TV when I work this kind of job just wouldn't work. I'd miss random nights every week. Online I can catch it when I'm free. As technology continues to make workloads lighter on workers, we will have more and more job flexibility, and more free time. Eventually we will cross a threshold where scheduled programming may work again, but in this time where technology is slowly changing most industries, both creative and manual, we don't (as a mass population) have the stability to consistently watch scheduled TV.

Cable was the first bullet. Once you had options, networks were hit. I believe adult swim was the second bullet. People my age had something to see late at night now tailored to them. No new generation watching late night. The final bullet in the back of the head was podcasts. Podcasting showed what interviews and conversations can be, and made it clear how plastic and synthetic late night shows are.
Late Night shows need to be culturally and socially relevant. While we have seen the format change with the evolution of media and how it‚Äôs consumed, also keep in mind Late Night was never designed for international audiences.  What Late Night TV was, was an aggregate of pop culture for media consumption. What is pop culture in a global society? It‚Äôs no longer localized to their immediate communities. People can afford to care less about their own culture and community, just as much as people can now care more and engage with foreign cultures and communities.  In that scope if people want their fix of popular culture entertainment, the late show has become a very archaic, and just does not reach the amount of people Twitter and YouTube does, and to a much more diverse audience.

Can confirm, this holds true for other countries as well. I'm 33, when i was a teen, it was kind of special to watch our own poltical comedy and satire shows with my dad on late night tv. If the episode particularly good or relevant, we'd even get an extension on our bedtime (usually my parents would send us to our rooms around 10pm so they could have some alone time). Now though? I have multiple TVs at home but we don't watch traditional live tv AT ALL. EVER. It's just not interesting. If there's a really good take/episode on political talkshows or satire shows, i can catch it online whenever i want. I don't plan my day around what show is on at what time. And it's the same with american late night as well. My partner and i love sitting down to watch monologues or political satire segments - but we do it over breakfast, if at all.  We really, really loved Hassan minhaj on Patriot Act. We watched that show religiously, every weekend over breakfast. We were extremely sad when it got cancelled.   I just don't care about all of the cult of personality though. I don't care who these people are, i care about their content. I also don't care about celebrities at all, so that's a huge part of late night that's just irrelevant to me, and why it's so convenient to just catch "comedy news" on youtube.   I think these shows would do really well if they just went to netflix (or another online streaming service). Large portions of their audience are already also watching online. The live component just isn't as important anymore today, i feel. I'd be really happy if partiot act came back :/

Welcome to the internet, Late Night. Your death was long ago, though you may have tried to find your way through it. TV as is stands just isn't the format that continues in this day and age. Information and entertainment was spread via specific time slots through a specific format, much like radio was. Radio was also slowly replaced by television, though still experienced in cars by responsible drivers. (I could go on about people in cars using their phones these days and causing the death and injury of thousands by day, but I digress). Information and entertainment is available at any time in this day and age. I posit that the internet is the death of Late Night, though it may have taken quite a long time.

Fun fact: heavy smoking appears to cause insomnia (it's largely from the nicotine). The entire concept of the late show on American television coincides with smoking being at its highest percentage of the population for 20 years - 1950-1970. While smoking began to decline through the 70s, the insomniac patterns were well-ingrained into television viewers by then. Perhaps sufficiently to power the late show boom of the 1980s.  By the 2000s however, late gen-x members and millennials who smoked much less would be coming into their own as adult prime time television viewers. I wouldn't be surprised if it's literally the decline in nicotine usage which is irreversibly reducing the demand for live late-night entertainment content in the home.

There's a pretty big elephant in the room regarding these shows... and that's the fact that if you don't agree with a very specific and narrow political ideology, most of these hosts go out of their way to antagonize your beliefs, or at very least make absolutely no effort to see other people's perspectives.  It used to be a very broad spectrum, you had left wing hosts, right wing hosts, moderate hosts, radical hosts, and hosts who didn't really take a stance one way or the other. And each of them had unique or interesting takes, whether you agreed with them or not each show felt completely different depending on who was speaking. Nowadays it doesn't feel that way... it just seems like a choice between 4 or 5 radical left wing hosts who all say the same things, and like 2 guys who just avoid politics completely. There's no space for moderates who still want to hear a bit of political news but don't want the entire show to be "orange man bad" - and there's certainly no space for anybody with right wing or even centrist views. It very much gives off the impression that all of Hollywood wants you to believe in very specific things otherwise you're "wrong" and "evil" for not agreeing with them.

I think the one thing you got wrong in this was to claim that it was an issue that Jimmy wasn't political and it hurt him. I'd say it was the opposite and that the death of late night is because it's political. Like, take Colbert. His show is so political it feels more like propaganda than comedy. I mean, look at how many cringey vaccine pushes he had where he had people dressed as a syringes dance. Who the fuck wants to watch that. The only people who would like that content are the people who obsessed with politics. Even a passer buy would be put off. I'd say this did more to kill late night as it just became insufferable. Really, the shift to politics has been what really killed these. The audience was being tired of being lectured and tired of unfunny Trump jokes and they ALL did it constantly. As for the writers strike, the reason most people shouldn't support it is simply because Hollywood can't write for shit nowadays so why should they get a raise? If anything, the low ratings of the show don't justify a pay bump. Simple economics.

I think the reason people equate the strikes to the hollywood elites is because these late night hosts make millions themselves and could take a paycut in order to restore the wages for the writers, but they'd rather bargain to have the unions comp for it.  While I don't know the details of why the wages decreased, it's possible the shows started making less and the hosts were still on their same massive contracted amount, but they couldn't reduce their star talent's pay so they opted for the writers.  If the hosts really are "nothing without their writers" then prove it and reduce your pay which is already too high. But maybe they don't actually care and it's all a virtue signaling.  Or maybe the hosts aren't willing to do it because they realize how unfunny their writers have been and they don't deserve a pay increase. Politics killed late shows. America got more partisan, and newer hosts were hired based on this. This alienated a large number of casual viewers. Conan and Fallon largely avoided this, however you could say it was a large factor in the general drop in viewership. Same thing happened to SNL. Id say Letterman became the catalyst for it all with his open criticism night after night of the Iraq War and Bush. Even if the criticism was right, people used to tune in for entertainment, laughter, and escapism, not to be constantly reminded of the same things the 24/7 news networks were also churning out.

James would ask him such standard questions and he would give the most delightfully bizarre answers. One time they were covering a news story about a woman breaking her husband out of prison and james was asking his crew if they would break their spouse or best friend out of prison and when he got to reggie, reggie said something like "I avoid this issue by befriending only noncorporeal beings" and james just went silent for a moment and then moved onto the next bit. It was stupendous.  Since no one asked:   Personally I don't really get the appeal of Fallon. Seth Meyers is the only late night show besides the daily show that actually feels in touch with activism and the youth perspective, but sometimes they stumble over the most basic stuff, like joke structure or anticipating their audience. For a really long time into quarantine, seth would still ask his nonexistent audience how they were doing before getting to the news. Now he has an audience again but he hasn't resumed asking people how they're doing, he just says "we hope you're doing well, now let's get to the news." I don't know why this interests me so much lol although it does feel sort of emblematic of the show's tendency to miscalculate their audience. Since it doesn't seem to affect you since you probably agree with their takes, you probably didn't even consider that late night's foray into becoming more political was a major turning point as well. A large portion of late night's audience shut that shit off the moment they and their opinions (the viewers) became the butt of the joke. Literally all of Hollywood has their "right and wrong" think, and they have made it abundantly clear over the past few years where they stand. For many of us, we decided "well fuck you too, then," shut off the TV and haven't looked back.

Interesting points.   Late-night TV died when Letterman moved on. Seth Myers is still fun, but that's been it for some time. Colbert is fine but exclusively political since Trump. Even before the pandemic,   Cordon said in interviews (before he became the anti-christ of late-night) they had no illusions about who was watching them that late at night (the morning!) with Carpool Karaoke, etc. YouTube was their target audience. They got far more revenue from YT than from broadcast.   The entire concept of 'talk shows' is entirely dated - they were one of the first TV formats and have LONG outlived their point. For a while with Carson (yeah, I am THAT old) it was an event to see who he had on - a breaking comic, a celeb you ONLY saw with him, or a regular fun guest - then it turned into a promotion machine - no movie star came on unless they had a movie to sell. All the conversations became canned.  Dick Cavett (so far as I recall) was not a late-night host - I think his show was on in first-run syndication. HE had amazing guests, long intelligent conversations and risked controversy. His show is a time capsule of the 60s-70s

As a fan of late night, I am a HUGE fan of Seth Meyers and believe that no one compares to him in late night. A Closer Look is always as engaging as John Oliver's "Last Week Tonight" segments, and they do 4 a week, albeit in a more political and less controversial light. He is INSANELY personable with his guests and is able to adapt and flow with ease due to his improv background. He comes across as genuine in his questions and answers, which is more to say than a lot of other late-night hosts. I used to be a Colbert fan until he started his own show- his comedy feels old and angry. Seth Meyers has adapted to his current audience and his love for his staff shines through the mundanity/horribleness of the current news. I truly believe Conan was the true king of late night, but Seth has picked up where Conan left off in a different way. He isn't Conan, but his interactions/collaborations with his writers show what an incredibly smart and strong crew they are. Keep Seth Meyers on air!

We saw Conan on tour in San Francisco in 2019. Purchased a VIP package that included a Meet & Greet backstage & a goodie bag full of merch. Conan is taller & thinner in person & very, very nice/patient with fans. He had other comedians as well as a band on that tour. It was a fun show & his staff was great to me (as a disabled/mobility impaired person that has difficulty with stairs.) I grew up watching Carson & Letterman. The Tonight Show & Late Night were about the only things on for an insomniac student to watch especially if you did not have cable in the 90s. I usually preferred the later night shows that come on after Johnny (Letterman, Conan, Ferguson) & I definitely liked Jimmy Fallon's show better when it was in the later time slot. They had some pretty great sketch parodies & it felt less like a game show. Fallon is very talented but not a great interviewer imo. My fave right now is probably Seth Meyers (he is a good interviewer & doesn't pull political punches) followed by Colbert. I don't watch any network tv anymore  except for those shows which I stream. I think there's a ton of baby boomers who still have cable and still watch the news during the day, and late night shows at night. I usually walk my dog at night while nobody's around (cuz she goes crazy around other dogs), and whenever I happen to glance into someone's front window, they're almost always watching either the news or a late night show.  Even my mom and stepdad still have cable and watch those shows - they just also happen to have Netflix and maybe Disney + (but they mostly only watch some of the hit shows when they come out, as opposed to just scrolling through and watching whatever catches their eye).  They're definitely a dying breed, and I'm not sure who will end up taking over for the current crop of guys (or who would even want to) - unless the shows just stop existing altogether, or if they morph into some sort of online/podcast type thing like what Conan's doing now.  To be somewhat fair to Leno, I think he's a comedian's comedian (all other comedians seem to revere him from back in the day, at least from what I always hear on Dana Carvey and David Spade's Fly on the Wall podcast, and some other podcasts), and I think he's super well-liked except for what he did to Conan.  Also to be somewhat fair to Corden, I disagree that most of these guys would know the names of random cameramen - they might have a few "main" guys who are always there or something, but I doubt they spend much time talking to most of them (whether it's cameramen or any other crew members that are more removed from the writing/performance itself). I think there's wayyyy more crew members than you think, so you're talking about remembering like 50-100 people who you don't interact very much with - not out of malice but just because you're all busy and you've got jobs to do, that largely don't intersect much.  I think Conan's a comedy genius, even moreso than these other guys, so he tends to keep things interesting - he was a writer for the longest time (on SNL and the Simpsons) so he knows how it works, he's a great performer, and he's great at improv/riffing, so he can basically do anything and make it fun.  I think SNL is also falling by the wayside, but I bet it's still going to be on for quite a while just because it's such a behemoth with so much history - and I'd imagine it still commands a decent audience every Saturday (and people then watch the clips on Youtube).

I am so, so for the writers guild association strike! People should be paid for their intellectual property and their contribution to a creative project. To diminish one's individual input is to diminish ANYONES input of labour in ANY field.  I can only hope the writers guild strike will force people to recognise that ANYTHING that we consume is typically the result of some unspoken hero, someone not loudly heralded in what is otherwise a loud, and venerated industry! I hope that this strike has knock on effects in all industries - in the service industries, where people making minimum wage are recognised as important elements in the field, in educational industries, where teachers are seen as imperative instruments in educating our new generation, and those working in delivery industries, where people are seen more as faceless forms of transportation of our most valuable goods.  Most of the people reading this are in the labour market, and we need to stick together. We don't need to disparage people working in the writing world as privileged and unappreciated, we need to understand that we are all part of labour force, that needs to unite, and negotiate for a common good.

I think that a large art of the late night problem is how in lockstep all the hosts seem to be when it comes to parroting and boosting Democratic Party talking points.  Always quick to point up Republican or right-wing peccadilloes but never giving left-wing or Democrat fiascoes or lies the same treatment.  They're all so unanimous it's like they all signed the same contract or something.  Now, only about 30% of the country votes Democrat, another 30% or so votes Republican and most of the rest describe themselves as "independent."  So they've been alienating a huge slice of the population for years or decades on end.  Not a great strategy for growth, long term.  Also not a mistake that their classic predecessors made, at least not in nearly the same degree.

Will probably get lost in the shuffle, but I wanted to tell a quick story about Fallon and Colbert. I was in NYC years ago and went to a Fallon taping and a Colbert taping. In the Fallon taping, he only ever interacted with guests and the Roots and got incredibly exasperated with a cue card holder, like he was seething.   Colbert's show happened to be on the day of a terrible snowstorm, all the guests had to cancel and NYC local guests ended up coming in. Colbert was super appreciative of everyone coming out to the show, he did the pre-taping Q&A. Then watched an animated cold open with us because he thought his writers did such a good job with it and wanted to see our reaction. He was incredibly personable and friendly.

Craig Ferguson will always be my favorite late night host. He saw the impending death of late night, and structured the whole show as a parody of the dated, repetitive late show format. He would tear up the cue cards, he did the monologue with a rabbit hand puppet, and his sidekicks were two interns in a horse costume and a gay robot skeleton. Once Letterman retired, late night was officially dead to Craig, so he retired too. And then James Corden took over. Ironic, isn‚Äôt it?

Half the country votes one way and the other half  the opposite. Kimmel even admitted it recently on a podcast. I‚Äôm not trying to start a debate on politics I‚Äôm just stating the truth about why they lost so much viewership and almost none of this was mentioned in this video. Something about Jimmy Fallon's inability to handle political topics sticks out to me. In college for history class I watched a documentary called "Dick Cavett's Vietnam" and it compiled clips from talk shows in the 60s and 70s where celebrities and the host Mr. Cavett were not afraid to debate politics live. Folks like Muhammad Ali went on the air to voice their opposition to the US intervention and they were not cut off or stopped for it. Between then and now something happened that changed the way talk shows work, and its that advertisers, aka people who funds the shows, are too afraid to rock the boat at all because if it means they lose even a cent of profits if they dare to take any stance at all they won't do it. This means that shows like Jimmy Fallon have zero edge, they are as safe as milk and that just isn't entertaining nor is it important. Talk shows are dying not just because they aren't funny anymore, but because they are completely detached from the rest of reality in terms of topics.  Nobody wanted to see Jimmy Fallon doing a floss competition and pretend there weren't riots in the streets.

Jimmy Fallon Album. Look it up
I was 24 when Johnny Carson retired in 1992.  He'd been a staple of middle school and high school for  me (and late Friday nights as a younger kid when I was granted the permission to stay up and watch him; the show was 90 minutes long until about 1979!)...this video is an absolutely excellent take on why late night TV is dying.  If you're still not convinced, go watch Johnny Carson TV and you'll see what I've missed so much for 31 years now.  Carson may not have been a perfect human, but he was the GOAT of  Late Night.  David Letterman was a good #2, at least until he became more political and seemingly bitter post-circa 2010.  Carson's show was focused on the guests (and occasionally the audience and even the staff); most of the late night hosts since then have been very self-oriented.  There is also a great 1979 interview that Mike Wallace did with Carson; it's in two parts on YouTube.  Carson's insights as to his own success, his role as a late-night host. and at times his obvious insecurity about the job he was doing are eye-opening.
I think one thing that makes it so clear that Seth Meyers and his team understand the shift in culture is the Corrections segment - which exists only on youtube and is also designed to drive engagement specifically TO the youtube videos throughout the week. He's also made several jokes on the show about how he knows most people watch A Closer Look online the next day and not the monologue by pointing out a callback he knows the online audience will miss. Corrections feels like the glimpse of where this could go. It's also extremely weird, not in a canned way but in a frequently over the top bizarre way that sometimes feels fresher than Oliver's weird bits (which are still wonderful).   The rotating cast daily show I think is also a fun idea - I've watched more daily show clips since Trevor left than I have in a long time, just to see each different hosts dynamic. They'd be smart to keep it going.  And honestly? talking about the credit due the writers? The daily show writers have been unbelievable since Trevor left in having to adapt week after week to a completely different host's personality, background and style. They deserve so much credit for that.

Man, I was watching Craig's and Conan's Writers' Strike (08) shows last week and fell into a stoned thought loop that was almost exactly this video. You had such good but distinct escapist shows on at 12.35 in 08. Shows that were made for that timeslot.  Recently, we had two clones of the 11.35 shows that didn't really provide escape. My main reason for bowing out of late night shows around 17 was the constant political humor about very unfunny stuff. Do people really want to hear about the country falling apart that late? Of course no one watches live anymore. 12.35 was made for insomniacs, stoners, geeky teens, and other weirdos up that late. Someone should've been taking advantage of that.   That said, at least Colbert and Meyers have a real interest in and capacity for political humor, so I can respect their shows even if I can't watch anymore.   If the networks were a bit smart:   11.35 Meyers on NBC against Colbert on CBS.  12.35 @midnight on CBS against (at least once a week) a prestige-level drama or comedy on NBC that could take advantage of the timeslot and give the network something noteworthy. I really feel like that could pop for them. Really, they should have a whole late night schedule, but that would be too risky to do all at once.   Kimmel can keep shilling for Disney on ABC, I guess.  The format truly is dead, though.  I hope Colbert doesn't make @midnight all politics. That thought sent me into a really bad high. üòÖ

Late Night is still trying to grasp an audience from a time when people could only make their marks on Hollywood, Whilst living (and completely aware that they are) in an era where celebrities come from the outback homes of small town folks who would NEVER get a shot from the spotlight due to their non-competitive nature, anxious bias, or country of origin. You could now find stars from a professional video editor from New York to a drunk depressed streamer from Estonia. Stars existing from a decentralized system is what Hollywood and Late Night failed to adjust themselves to from the transitional decade of the 2010's, and so they're basically trying to catch up from a bus that went past them whilst trying to save their pride and status.  Conan, the only comedian that got swept under the rug during the transition period, was the ONLY late night comedian that found absolute stability with his Late Night gig before ending it. Leno's abuse towards Conan gave him a dignified path to a better work life than any of the late night hosts. He truly is happy from the clips I've seen of him online, and I am very proud that he was able to surpass a dickings from prime time TV life and entered a better career online.

Hey @Eddy Burbank ‚Äî  Late night comedy still rakes in millions of dollars via YouTube every damn day ‚Äî not even just when they release new episodes, but every second of the day a clip from their show is being watched by someone on YouTube, sometimes clips released like 10 years ago. Are people watching the shows on cable? No. But if a tree falls in the forest when no one around but it still makes millions of dollars from ad revenue, does anyone care if no one is around? Mind you ‚Äî neither James Cordon or Trevor Noah were fired ‚Äî they both stepped down. They both would have seen their contracts renewed over and over again because they made content people watched online and when it comes to television, a late night comedy show is insanely cheap to produce compared to just about every other kind of show.  Your dream of hosting a late night show not only does not need to die, but you are closer to it than ever before ‚Ä¶ Here is what I would suggest: Rent out a venue, get some writers together to write some comedy bits, line up some guests (stand up comics would probably be easiest interviews), then film your comedy bits and interview in front of a live audience (free tickets) in LA and stream it live on YouTube, then cut all the segments up into smaller videos which you upload onto your YouTube channel as if you‚Äôre a real damn TV show. You already have a head start because you have a YouTube following. By doing this four nights a week, you‚Äôll be able to flood YouTube with tons of quality content, far easier than producing 30 minute video essays ‚Äî and that should translate to much more online revenue (the more videos you have, the more opportunities for views and thus the more money you make‚Ä¶ I think ).   You don‚Äôt even need a television network as the middle man because no one watches television networks anyway.   Oh. And while I agree that Seth Meyers is the best late night host on the air right now, I have to beg you to not follow his example and wear a damn suit. You look really nice in a suit. I mean. I would get a stylist to get you a suit that fits your personality better (I am thinking skinny ties, lots of blues, shirts with a pattern. Probably just want to copy John Oliver‚Äôs suits.)

There isn't much to say about modern late night - Carpool Karaoke, Trump jokes, pointless gimmicks. It's so dull, so vapid, so... pointless. Whatever people say about SNL applies way more to the state of late night now. It probably started with Letterman and Leno dragging on, Letterman phoning it in for a while, doing interviews with fucking Tea Party dopes for god knows what reason, and generally being a bore. Corden was just the most obvious example of the aura of unlikeability spreading among a dying medium. Anyone would find it hard to succeed with the advent of streaming content on top of everything else we suffer in modern society.  Maybe Corden poisoned the well for everyone, to some degree. Even if he didn't come across as a total prick, the Carpool Karaoke spam and all the other gimmicks were so tedious. Like that singing in the crosswalk bit - how is that entertaining, inconveniencing random people to sate the man's ego? Stop singing, dude. Write some jokes.  And yeah, I got beyond sick of seeing dumb celebrities stringing along through Fallon's stupid games or whatever. Just don't care. It's not interesting. I do think Colbert was unfairly judged by the standards of Colbert Report, but that also doesn't make the late night show worth watching.  The things late night did are so accessible through social media/Youtube now, we're overloaded with information as is, no one wants cable, and celebrities are no longer mystical entities captivating our attention. Perfect storm.

How I (someone old enough to have seem my 1st Tonight Show in 1977) watch the late night shows (pre-strike): I start with Colbert's monologue on the TV, then check what game or bits Jimmy Fallon's doing. After that, I'll watch whichever guests I care to see on all the shows, otherwise turn the TV off until the 12:35 shows start. Then I catch Seth's news monologues and Closer Looks - or whichever comedy bits he does most Tuesdays. Then, I'd check James Corden during the break, then whoever's guests I want to see (Corden's panel, of course). I loved when I'd catch Reggie Waats' question. And anytime later, I'll watch Jimmy Kimmel's monologue on YouTube.   SNL I always watch live when it's a new one. It's my all-time favorite show since 1976. I nowadays watch that show on DVD or internet, sometimes watching individual sketches from all eras on YouTube.  I'd hate for late night shows to disappear completely from TV. Colbert, Meyers, Bill Maher, John Oliver, and Kimmel helped get me through the Trump administration. Kimmel's monologues are right there with the aforementioned these days. As it is, I miss new shows from Craig Ferguson, who was right up there with Johnny, Dave, and Conan in excellence. Hos was one show I stayed tuned to to the end, though I didn't miss the best parts of Conan, then Seth.

I do mostly agree, but I have a comment about restaurants observing allergies. That is not always the case.   Im a type 1 diabetic and if I order a diet coke, I need a diet coke.  I have to give myself a shot of insulin for all carbs I eat or drink.  Ive been given regular coke many times. To many, this isnt a huge deal, but if I drink a regular coke and think it is diet I will not count that into how much insulin I hive myself.  It can really ruin my day and if its egregious enough my blood sugar could go high and I could end up in a coma. There are many cases where restaurants are awesome and will really look out for you and take care of making sure you got the right thing, but other times Ive had employees think I'm just being difficult and ignore my requests. So maybe James is just using it as an excuse, but after having a few restaurants almost kill me im not too quick to think all restaurants are following allergy procedures.

The early years of Late Night w/ Conan O'Brien were some of the greatest episodes of Late Night TV put to air. His nervous energy and his "throw every comedy bit at the wall and see what sticks" mentality was upholding the tradition started by Ernie Kovacs, refined by Johnny, and perfected by Letterman. Now TV viewing habits have shifted so dramatically in the last 10 years that I don't see such a thing coming back to late night broadcast TV any time soon, if ever. The networks will want to play it safe and if they do something outrageous, it will likely be paywalled on their streaming services instead of free over-the-air like it used to.
The talk shows are what Noam Chomsky would refer to as Manufacturing Consent. And all the talk show have lost credibility and become tools of the elite. Watching them only contributes to our loss of freedoms.

I have my degree in screenwriting and I haven't done anything with it besides the fact that I have a BA and worked in design for a few years. Soon after graduating it became clear how abyssmal the industry was getting and how impossible it was to get a gig if you didn't have family or know someone. I really think my passion for it would have died had I known the conditions writers were in at the time. I was in school during the late night shift and even went to one of Craig's last shows the year he retired. Like you, a lot of my dreams have faded, but even now I have this wish of being able to do what younger me wanted. I think this is why I was pursing animation storyboarding for a while because it combined the two things I loved: drawing and writing. Growing up when writing was at a high really fooled me into thinking I'd be able to make it too. But, like in 2007-08, I am glad to see the strike happen and people fight for proper pay and a sustainable career. I only have hopes that this will help not only those in writing positions now but also those looking to break in, setting the path for the future of tv and film. Thank you for mentioning the strike and thank you for the wonderful video.

Another reason it died is that it's all just sugar-coated cringe or regurgitated CNN stories.  I usually do watch Seth's stuff whenever it comes out because it crosses my feed, but I don't actively seek it out.  Conan adapted and puts out great content and is a person I watch/listen to whenever I see it, rerun or new.  The Daily Show tanked when Noah took over.  It lasted for a little bit before the concept of intellectual satire attacking crucial ideas and critical issues, regardless of what radically leaned idiot preaches them.  After Noah took over, the guests started to skew less and less of authors and something like Jon interviewing them and really exploring deep concepts and turned into having artist/actors come on like any other generic late show.  The best the Daily Show has been in ages has been after Noah left and the cast of the show got their chances to host.  Jordan Klepper would be an amazing host all around being closest to Jon in terms of being a solid comedian that also understand the art of the interview, Desi Lydic would do well if they felt they needed to "break the mold" again on a host, I think Roy Wood Jr. does better as a field reporter, but he did well as temp host, and Ronny Chieng would honestly do well as a host too (although I think, like Roy, his interactions in the field are gold).  None of them felt anywhere near as sugar-coated as Noah was.  Then again, I don't think it would be possible for anyone to beat Jon's latest crusade in being allowed to tear into people with honesty and rationality.

I'm in New Zealand and we just don't have access to a lot of these shows. So I started to download them (illegally). And it became part of my routine. I'd wake up, put on the previous day's "Daily Show with Jon Stewart" and I'd go through my journal to sort out my day (what I needed to get done). It was a great start to the day. The piracy sources changed the time the video was available and it kind of screwed things up.  The thing I LOVE about late show TV is that they've kind of curated the news into something digestible. I can watch, feel outrage, but also laugh at the absurdity of it all.  Whenever The Daily Show was off for a few weeks I found myself a bit lost. I want to know what's going on in the States because a lot of that stuff is coming here. The same rhetoric, talking points, techniques for capturing the conversation etc. Does it really matter if we're not watching that content on TV? Like if it's on the Internet? The audience changes the vibe a lot for me. The fact that they're a lot freer with putting the content on YouTube nowadays is a great move (although I do worry about YouTube holding all of the cards here).

I know theres used to be more programms about music or even concerts being shown, but that was mostly left behind in the last century/ only brought up for special days/events. Music television? Either anything but music or being a very very niche thing, ). One of the biggest moments of Colbert for me personally is when he asked Keanu what happens when we die, perhaps setting up for a more or less simple answer of how Reeves feels about the afterlife, but instead it allowed Reeves to draw on his experiences and respond "I know that the people who love us will miss us", and while that may not seem particularly deep to some people to those who have experienced such close familial loss (including both Reeves and Colbert), it was a deeply poignant moment of wisdom that isn't often heard in a late night interview. I had recently lost my brother at the time that clip surfaced and it hit me in the same way it hit Colbert in that moment. Sure I may not laugh at all his segments, but I really appreciate that moment happening.

On Late Night, Colbert makes his background in philosophy evident every night. And while he may not do the acting bits like Johnny's, Mighty Carson Art Players, he has been increasingly adding his own vocalization to the show--notably when he did a musical number with David Byrne. And the relationship he has had with his two  bandleaders has been a thing of beauty to watch as he nurtures these performers into becoming the best version of themselves that they can be. I do love The Roots and miss the energy they bring to Fallon. I'm most bummed when Seth or Colbert are on vacation and I'm short content to watch when I get back home after my morning drive. I think that internet based media consumption isn't the sole cause of the decline of Late Night shows. I think that the broader fracturing of the monoculture that existed in America from the 70's-2000's is the main driver. There is so much content being produced on the whole that it is basically impossible to watch/listen to all of it, and consumers have the ability to choose their own media cocoons; blocking out all the other aspects of broader pop culture they don't want to interact with. All of this contributes to an environment where late night shows can't maintain their relevance if they want to exists as a pop culture variety show. There just isn't enough interesting content for an individual to watch a whole of episode of late night and "mass appeal" as a concept is not as powerful as it once was.

THANK YOU for going into the writers strike! Television and streaming are changing rapidly, and greedy execs are using those changes to take advantage of the creatives that are the back bone of the production pipeline by doing massive layoffs then rehiring for low pay, refusing to increase minimum raises fairly, and implementing/investing in AI to "hopefully" replace their jobs all together while using their previous work as fodder for the code. It's already affecting more than just writers so we can expect to see even more union strikes about the same thing, and supporting them is so important! Great quality vid as usual eddy! keep it up

Colbert and Meyers are the best
The podcast boom of the past few years has been great when it comes to celebrity interviews. There's no overblown sketches, no getting dolled up to talk to someone for 15 minutes, no having to wait until the audience stops unrealistically laughing. These interview podcasts are more casual, personal and feel like real conversations. Those that film their podcasts show that the guests usually just wear their comfort clothes for when they're not working. The conversations are more focused on the guest as a person than as a celebrity. They just seem to be far more charming to me than all these late night shows.   There are a lot of good interview podcasts, but my go to is Inside of You with Michael Rosenbaum which I feel perfectly captures the overall vibe of these podcasts.

I never watched late night in cable TVs prime because it was on after my bed time. I never watch late night as an adult because I refuse to get cable. When I think of network television, I feel contempt. 65% commercial 35% content with the most cookie cutter, ratings-safe writing possible under the complete control of network execs.  The only way network TV can recover is if writers get control back over what content they can make and kick the suits out of the creative room entirely. Eliminate interruptive advertising. And for real, the few times I do see network TV, the show is broken up by four minute blocks of two or three commercials repeating over and over and over again. It drives viewers A W A Y.  I don't have much hope for this, I'm pretty sure network TV is going the way of the radio. Only installed in places of convenience: waiting room lobbies and hotel rooms. It just can't compete with the instant gratification the internet offers, even if they aggressively control how much of their content gets online. Because in that space there's already infinitely more content that's better in every way except production value.
More people watch clips of these shows on youtube than the actual show.

I'm glad that you brought up the WGA strike. People really don't understand the pay (or lack thereof) that the average writer in television and film gets. Someone on twitter posted a picture of their father's residual pay from a bunch of SNL episodes he helped write, and it was a total of less than $20 for what must have been 50+ episodes. Some of the residuals were literally one cent per episode.
Conan and Craig Ferguson were the only ones I went out of my way to watch back in the day.
I kinda just see late night as a whole like I see modern news tv like Fox News, CNN, MSNBC, etc. They all just have this layer of inauthenticity in what they say and how they say what they say. I'm sure the blame isn't solely on the hosts and should be put on the executives who stifle their views. The leashes they put on their hosts causes me to distrust anything they say and know that the hosts themselves sometimes don't believe what their saying. The politics are usually one sided without ever going into controversies on their side.   For example, you're not going to see a breakdown from Seth Myers on how the DNC is trying to shoehorn Biden as the automatic candidate for 2024 without any discussion or debate regardless of his many faults and aging mind. Maybe Seth would like to talk about it but I doubt the puppet masters that own him and others like him would ever let him say anything that would go against what the network wants to put forward.  I think the future is that talented talk show hosts with actual views they hold start their own independent shows/podcasts online. Someone who's excelled at this is Jon Stewart. His ability to go outside what is typically said in politics allows him to have an independent view that people agree with.
I worked at NBC during Leno‚ÄôO‚ÄôBriengate.  NBC wanted to capitalize on Leno‚Äôs rating‚Äôs and popularity but also saw he‚Äôs tenure coming to an end.  So they carved out The Jay Leno show for him and injected O‚ÄôBrien into The Tonight Show.  The transition was messy along with internal confusion when it came to having two late night shows.  Ratings dropped, NBC panicked, and moved to quickly inject Leno back which made things messier and more confusing for the two comedians.  Public perception successfully made it a Leno vs O‚ÄôBrien thing instead of calling it for what it really was, an NBC debacle.

100% agreed on Conan. I discovered him in the mid-to-late 90s, somewhere around middle school and high school. I didn't have a TV in my room, but as I was getting older I was starting to stay up later. In particular I stayed up during summer break, and at the time my dad was working swing shift. Conan's show started around the time my dad got home, so we'd watch it together. It was partly that I had a show to share with my dad, but partly what you said‚ÄîI found Conan on my own, and was hooked on how silly he was and how great his gift was for rolling with the punches; he could turn material that flopped into something gold with his reactions.
