Late Night will come back when Hollywood invests in creative people instead of the empty suits being promoted today.  Why is Kim Kardashian an interesting guest?  It's a trick question.  She isn't.  Her family are scammers.  She goes on talk shows to promote her scammy family.  The singing segments should be the canary in the coalmine that producers hired today aren't interested in new ideas, just distractions.  Hollywood thinks we're stupid.  When Hollywood stop thinking that we're stupid, I'll expect people like Michael Che or Charlemagne, Wanna Sykes, George Leguizamo to get a talk show and they get guests from this century who aren't some cardboard cutout of a human being like Harry "ooh look I'm wearing mummy's clothes, aren't I naughty, fuck me Olivia Wilde I don't care that you're married" Stiles.  Frankly, I think Hollywood has a sociopath/narcissism problem.  As power changes hands over the years and companies become increasingly consolidated under the same banner, I think that what used to be a tendency for executives to have a lizard mindset in terms of running a business has become standard operating procedure, and I'm no doc, doc, but I know enough that sociopaths (ie. those who don't have any evident sense of sympathy for the feelings of others, aside from pretending to be compassionate for their own convenience) don't relate to others, therefore they don't relate to an audience.  It's become the case that in order to see a movie, one needs to sign up to particular streaming service.  Forget going to the theater, or anything like that.  The public love a complicated paywall, don't we?  Don't we?!   I don't think so.  That reserved seating thing they do at chain theaters is pretty dumb, I think, too.  It's as if corporate America, along with the entertainment industry, seek not to reach out to us, but to come up with what they think should appease us -- finally, a 3,546,864th singing competition!!!! -- in hope that this will grow their balance sheet, when the whole point of the entertainment industry is giving the public what we want.  To put another way, just like with the rest of mainstream corporate America, the entertainment industry has been seeking to automate creativity with the bullshit (Ex. reality television, recycled movie franchises, comic books everywhere, everywhere, the horror, the horror..) that we see today.  What good we do see is few and far between.  For every Seth Meyers we get the Jimmies (I'm the opposite opinion, I can't watch Fallon and Kimmel is closer to Conan but I don't watch Kimmel much either as with the rest of Hollywood, he's merely imitating what came before) and James Cordon.  I'm not sure Stephen Colbert is cut to do what Letterman and Carson did, but Conan certainly can, and has long proven it.  We see right here, the best are on the sidelines.  That's the problem here, I think, rather than the hosts themselves.

Eddy thank you so much for spreading awareness about production workers in the media and the WGA strike. I work in animation at one of the biggest companies and because of the name recognition people assume I must be making 6 digits a year when in reality it's nowhere near that much. The WGA strike will hopefully pave the way for ALL productions in the future. No one deserves to work in TV but if we do we still deserve to live in decent living accommodations. Currently, I had to move back to my hometown and commute an hour to LA for work because of the cost of living close to the studios. I know many writers or production people doing the same, or if they are from out of state feeling the need to stay in the unbelievably priced area just to be around a support system.

i think, like you said, pop culture has just become more about open access to celebrity culture and we‚Äôre more interested in ‚Äú‚Äùbackstage‚Äù‚Äù looks at celebrities on twitter and tiktok. we‚Äôre not just relying on interviews to build that parasocial relationship anymore, and that‚Äôs largely due to social media and obviously the pandemic that (mostly) had everyone in a somewhat similar position of being stuck at home. despite out of touch videos like the ‚Äúimagine‚Äù one, quarantine became this time of more ‚Äú‚Äùcandid‚Äù‚Äù looks at celebrities that just wasn‚Äôt replicable with late night tv because those more ‚Äúunpolished‚Äù personalities were actually being curated by the celebrity (and/or their team) in their tweets or on their instagram stories or whatnot. there‚Äôs no more visible middle man like a late night host to provide that glimpse into the celeb‚Äôs life.  sorry for the long comment lol. i took a pop culture class this semester in uni and it was really interesting to study the shift in celebrity culture and how it relates to the question of access! great video and thank you for the shoutout to screenwriters. means a lot as an aspiring screenwriter. :)

I discovered Craig Ferguson when I was a freshman in high school. His show was like a YouTuber with a small dedicated community. The whole show felt like Craig and his staff was just trying to make themselves laugh. With times where the whole show got derailed by some terrible joke that is so over played they laugh at it then pause and realize how terrible/over done the joke is and start laughing again. Then shift in professionalism from the Late show with David Letterman on CBS to former junky and Scotsman Craig Ferguson tries to talk about the news with hand puppets and an actual robot skeleton named Geoff who throw sexual innuendo at each other. That scenario felt like early YouTube or twitch where you got to be in on something that was not known to anyone but was the greatest/funniest thing ever to you.

I really think the fascination with late night started going down when social media started becoming more popular. Because before, it felt like talk shows were rare times when you could watch a celebrity being themselves, and hear about their stories. Now, everybody knows everything that is happening in that second through social media, and the "magic" that was there decades ago just isn't there anymore.
